alert.note: Alert for Clinton; Franklin (New York) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 02 at 2:21PM EDT until July 02 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: The National Weather Service in Burlington has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Northwestern Clinton County in northern New York... Northeastern Franklin County in northern New York... * Until 530 PM EDT. * At 221 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain across the warned area. Between 4 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.5 to 1.5 inches in 3 hours. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by heavy rain. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Bryants Mill, Burke, Chateaugay, Merrill, Malone, Churubusco, Earlville, Owls Head, Brainardsville, Chasm Falls, Burke Center, Whippleville, Wolf Pond, Harrigan, Standish, North Burke and Duane Center. This includes the following streams and drainages... East Branch Saint Regis River, Ouleout Creek, SLOPE: 21 -, East Branch Deer Creek, Tait Brook, Chateaugay River, SLOPE: 20 -, Branch Brook, Cold Brook, Flynn Brook, Duane Stream, Fishpole Outlet, Debar Brook, Middle Branch Trout River, Little Trout River, Thurber Brook, East Branch Little Salmon River, Trout River, Little Salmon River, Collins Brook, SLOPE: 23 -, SLOPE: 12 - North Branch Saranac River, Allen Brook, Brandy Brook, Ingraham Stream, Crandall Brook, Snake Brook, Boardman Brook, Cove Brook, Deer River, East Branch Trout River, North Branch Great Chazy River, Salmon River and Hatch Brook. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...0.5-1.5 INCHES IN 3 HOURS
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
